case_title: Mst. Allah Rakhi vs Murid Hussain Shah And Other

accussed_details.name: Mst. Allah Rakhi
allegation: Improper possession of property exceeding her rightful share under Muhammadan Law

complaint_summary: Murid Hussain Shah challenged the validity of a family settlement that transferred property to Mst. Allah Rakhi, alleging undue influence, collusion, and improper documentation.
investigation_summary: The court examined documentary evidence, including entries in Wajib-ul-Arz from 1904 and 1927-28, and oral testimonies to determine whether the family followed custom or Muhammadan Law in succession matters.
judgment_summary: The court held that the family followed Muhammadan Law in succession matters, invalidating the family settlement due to lack of proper registration and stamping. Mst. Allah Rakhi was entitled to 20 squares of land, while Murid Hussain Shah regained possession of 20 squares.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal partially allowed; judgment of trial court varied.
legal_arguments: Applicability of Muhammadan Law versus custom in succession matters.
Validity of family settlement due to lack of registration and stamping.
Undue influence alleged in the settlement process.
assets: 160 squares of land left by Punnun Shah
40 squares initially allotted to Mst. Allah Rakhi

witness_statement.Maulvi Akhtar Ali: Testified regarding the family settlement process.
witness_statement.Ch. Abdus Salam: Recorded statements of parties during the settlement.

key_issues: Applicability of Muhammadan Law versus custom.

maxims.Customary Law: Custom must be proven by evidence and cannot be extended by analogy.

legal_terms.Wajib-ul-Arz: A document recording customary practices during settlement operations.
legal_terms.Mutation: Legal process of transferring property ownership.

words_and_phrases.Male Lineal Descendant: Direct male offspring of a deceased owner.
words_and_phrases.Life Interest: Right to use property during one's lifetime.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the succession of property left by Punnun Shah, an issueless zamindar. The court invalidated a family settlement due to improper documentation and upheld Muhammadan Law as the governing principle for succession. Mst. Allah Rakhi retained 20 squares of land, while Murid Hussain Shah regained possession of 20 squares.
